title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: The Magical Code Menu in RStudio  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our March Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

For many R users, RStudio is just an excellent environment to write their code. Compared to the Rgui program included with the R installer, RStudio offers a clean, organized way to write code, view results, and organize their projects. However, RStudio offers many more features to help you out. In this presentation we're going to do a deep dive into the 'Code' menu which has many tools for writing cleaner, more reusable code and making certain tedious tasks easy. The end goal is to write better, more reusable code with less work.

Kenneth Fairchild is a Senior Consultant at Sawtooth Software where he specializes in Conjoint market research surveys. Kenneth's R interests are in automatic tasks, optimizing workflows, and generating high-quality deliverables for end-clients.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Stacked Ensemble Modeling with Tidy Data Principles  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our April Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

Stacked ensemble modeling is a statistical modeling technique that involves training a model to combine the outputs of many constituent models. The technique has been shown to increase predictive performance in a variety of settings. This talk will introduce {stacks}, a free and open-source R software package for stacked ensemble modeling that aligns with tidy data principles. The package’s functionality is closely aligned with the {tidymodels}, a collection of packages providing a unified interface to diverse statistical modeling techniques.

Simon Couch is a developer on open source R packages for statistical modeling. He is currently an undergraduate studying statistics at Reed College and formerly an intern at RStudio. Simon was awarded the 2021 John M. Chambers Statistical Software Award for {stacks}.

title: Oslo useR! Group: {ggstatsplot}: An R Package for {ggplot2}-Based Plots With Statistical Details  [Virtual] , Norway, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
{ggstatsplot} is an extension of the {ggplot2} package for creating
graphics with details from statistical tests, included in the information-rich plots themselves.
In a typical exploratory data analysis workflow, data visualization and statistical modeling are two different phases: visualization informs modeling, and modeling in turn can suggest a different visualization method, and so on and so forth.
The central idea of {ggstatsplot} is simple: combine these two phases into one in the form of graphics with statistical details, which makes data exploration simpler and faster!

[Bio]
Indrajeet Patil is a Postdoctoral Researcher at the Center for Humans and Machines, Max Planck Institute for Human Development, Berlin. He has a Ph.D. in cognitive neuroscience and specializes in investigating the psychological and neural basis of moral judgment and decision-making. He is also an active R package developer and part of the {easystats} team.

title: Sydney Users of  R Forum (SURF): AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit - Sydney 2021, Australia, Australia
description:
Registration is required on the AlphaZetta site - links below.

The AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit is a unique conference experience, built around experts sharing their knowledge, use cases, best practice and having time for meaningful interactions. It is not vendor driven - there’s no booths or selling and no big crowds - we expect only ~150 attendees. The summit provides insightful presentations, fantastic networking and discussion time at great value!

We are delighted that the next GAS will be held in Sydney on Friday 5th March at the Manly Pacific Hotel. Further details including the agenda can be found here ( https://alphazetta.ai/event/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020/ ).

The day starts with presentations on the current state of the analytics market and key trends to look for in the future. The second section is about inspiring attendees with keynotes from Volt Bank on creating a new business based on data and analytics and from Raiffeisen Bank on building an analytics team to provide true value to the whole organisation.

The afternoon focuses on innovation and implementation. We have presentations from some of Australia’s exciting startups (Volt, Adgile Media, Self Assured Pty Ltd) who are using analytics to disrupt their markets. To close, we will hear a keynote on how to deliver analytics and increase AI adoption.

The Summit venue is the Novotel Pacific, Manly which is right on the ocean beach, with lunch and dinner included.

All up, at just $350 for standard tickets, it’s a conference like no other!

title: Melbourne Users of R Network (MelbURN): AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit - Sydney 2021, Australia, Australia
description:
Registration is required on the AlphaZetta site - links below.

The AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit is a unique conference experience, built around experts sharing their knowledge, use cases, best practice and having time for meaningful interactions. It is not vendor driven - there’s no booths or selling and no big crowds - we expect only ~150 attendees. The summit provides insightful presentations, fantastic networking and discussion time at great value!

We are delighted that the next GAS will be held in Sydney on Friday 5th March at the Manly Pacific Hotel. Further details including the agenda can be found here ( https://alphazetta.ai/event/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020/ ).

The second section is about inspiring attendees with keynotes from Volt Bank on creating a new business based on data and analytics and from Raiffeisen Bank on building an analytics team to provide true value to the whole organisation.

The afternoon focuses on innovation and implementation. We have presentations from some of Australia’s exciting startups (Volt, Adgile Media, Self Assured Pty Ltd) who are using analytics to disrupt their markets. To close, we will hear a keynote on how to deliver analytics and increase AI adoption.

The Summit venue is the Novotel Pacific, Manly which is right on the ocean beach, with lunch and dinner included.

All up, at just $350 for standard tickets, it’s a conference like no other!

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event: Why R? - Gwynn Sturdevant - Efficient computation with R  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

- stream https://youtu.be/mnDgzORc8p8

- speaker Gwynn Sturdevant https://www.nzgwynn.com/
- webinars http://whyr.pl/webinars/
- subscribe http://whyr.pl/subscribe/
- slack http://whyr.pl/slack/
- meetup http://tiny.cc/WarsawRUG

# Speaker
Dr. Gwynn Sturdevant is a post-doctoral fellow at Harvard Business School working on the Science of Science. In her most recent position, she worked on analytical projects in the rail and the aviation sectors including: improving Terminal Arrival Efficiency Rate estimation, developing an algorithm to predict train arrival times in a multi-agency rail operating environment, and developing methods to produce unbiased algorithmic results. Dr. Sturdevant developed an extensive Shiny application to assist in balancing trials as a post-doctoral fellow with Ken Kleinman (University of Massachusetts, Amherst and Harvard University). Dr. Sturdevant has a PhD in Statistics from the University of Auckland, the birthplace of R, where she studied under Thomas Lumley (University of Auckland and University of Washington) and Ross Ihaka. She focused on finding long-term effects, after cessation of treatments, when noisy measurements cross a threshold in biometric data

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event: Workshop Generalized Linear Models Part 2  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

New year, new meetup! We're back in February with part 2 of the Generalized Linear Models workshop by Bodo Winter.

In part one, Bodo Winter gave an introduction to linear models and generalized linear models. This second workshop will introduce participants to mixed models, which are otherwise known as multilevel models or sometimes also hierarchical linear models. These models are crucial for dealing with cases of non-independence, such as when multiple data points are collected from the same individual, or from the same school, district, institution, country, or any other grouping variable. After a brief conceptual introduction, the workshop gives a quick tutorial on how to use the lme4 and afex packages to fit a generalized linear mixed effects model in R.

Please feel welcomed even if you didn’t make it to the first session as Bodo will begin with a very quick recap of part one anyway.

In case you want to see what was covered in part one, here is a link to a recording of the first session: https://bit.ly/35CwxVz

A repo with access to the hands-on materials will be distributed closer to the date of the workshop.

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by: Oslo useR! - {ggstatsplot}: An R Package for {ggplot2}  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

{ggstatsplot}: An R Package for {ggplot2}-Based Plots With Statistical Details

[Abstract]
{ggstatsplot} is an extension of the {ggplot2} package for creating
graphics with details from statistical tests, included in the information-rich plots themselves.
In a typical exploratory data analysis workflow, data visualization and statistical modeling are two different phases: visualization informs modeling, and modeling in turn can suggest a different visualization method, and so on and so forth.
The central idea of {ggstatsplot} is simple: combine these two phases into one in the form of graphics with statistical details, which makes data exploration simpler and faster!

[Bio]
Indrajeet Patil is a Postdoctoral Researcher at the Center for Humans and Machines, Max Planck Institute for Human Development, Berlin. He has a Ph.D. in cognitive neuroscience and specializes in investigating the psychological and neural basis of moral judgment and decision-making. He is also an active R package developer and part of the {easystats} team.

title: R-Ladies Bari: LinkedIn & le sue (quasi) infinite potenzialità  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:

In questo evento faremo qualcosa di veramente diverso.
Vogliamo tenere un workshop su come utilizzare Linkedin in modo efficiente e su come creare un miglior Personal Branding.
Potrai quindi imparare come:
* Aumentare il numero di contatti
* Cercare lavoro e creare alert
* Gruppi su LinkedIn: questi sconosciuti
* Postare contenuti su LinkedIn
* Netiquette
Non ci sarà solo una parte teorica ma anche esercizi pratici da seguire per apprendere tecniche efficaci.
La nostra straordinaria speaker per questo workshop è Sabrina Pittaluga.
Sabrina attualmente ricopre il ruolo di Talent Research Lead per l'area CEMA (Central and Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa) presso l'ufficio di Milano di BCG – Boston Consulting Group. Le attività che segue includono Sourcing & recruiting di posizioni senior e Market Intelligence.
Don't hesitate to join us, looking forward to hearing you all!

title: Campus useR Group Frankfurt: February meeting: Let's git togetheR!  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Git provides a fantastic infrastructure for version control and for collaboration on joint projects. Yet some of us might feel a little overwhelmed setting it up for the first time or understanding its more complex features.

In our February meeting, we will start off by showing how to set up git in RStudio and how to use it. We will then simulate a collaborative team project in which some of us make changes, others work on forked files and others just track how these changes become visible when pulling the latest version. We hope this will foster our understanding of git/github, and be a little fun, too.

There is no need to prepare anything, but you might want to set up a github account prior to the meeting. As always, R users of all backgrounds, at all levels of expertise and with all degrees of imposter syndrome are welcome. This will be yet another great opportunity to learn from each other.

title: R-Ladies Edinburgh: Participation of women and non-binary students in the mathematical sciences  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
description:
In the second meetup of January 2021, we're joined by Mary Llewellyn. Mary is a PhD student in Statistics at the University of Edinburgh and the co-founder and co-lead of the Piscopia Initiative.

Tackling the participation crisis of women and non-binary students in the mathematical sciences
The Piscopia Initiative (http://www.piscopia.co.uk) was founded in 2019 to tackle the participation crisis in mathematics postgraduate research programmes. In this talk, we will share the experiences of women and non-binary students in mathematics, as well as our own, and our plans for the future to change the landscape of mathematics.

Password for the Zoom session will be sent out on the day of the event. Find out local time of your event at https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=RLadies+Edinburgh+-+28+Jan+2021+Meetup&iso=20210128T1730&ah=1.

---

R-Ladies is a worldwide organization whose mission is to promote gender diversity in the R community.

A question we often get is "Are men welcome to attend this event?"

As a diversity initiative, the mission of R-Ladies is to achieve proportionate representation by encouraging, inspiring, and empowering people of genders currently underrepresented in the R community. R-Ladies’ primary focus, therefore, is on supporting minority gender R enthusiasts to achieve their programming potential, by building a collaborative global network of R leaders, mentors, learners, and developers to facilitate individual and collective progress worldwide.

**As such, we strongly encourage cis-men who attend this event to come as guests of R-Ladies who are minority genders (including but not limited to cis/trans women, trans men, non-binary, genderqueer, agender).**

All attendees are strongly encouraged to review the R-Ladies Code of Conduct (https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct) and must abide by it.

title: R-Ladies Edinburgh: The ABC of ABC  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
description:
In our February 2021 meetup we're joined by Isabella Deutsch. Bella is a PhD student in Statistics at the University of Edinburgh.

The ABC of ABC: Workflows and Challenges of Approximate Bayesian Computation

After a brief introduction to approximate Bayesian computation (ABC), we take a look at practical examples and discuss how to implement them. Special attention will be given to potential hurdles, illustrated through my current research on self-exciting point processes.

Password for the Zoom session will be sent out on the day of the event.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {R-Ladies Toolbox Series} Part 2: Presenting Results   [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
R-Ladies Toolbox Series - Essentials for women and minority genders in academia, science and data analysis presents:

Presenting Results by Manasi Mahadik (R-Ladies Mumbai)

Calling all students, academics, and women in science! R-Ladies Freiburg presents a five-part guest series aimed at women and gender minorities in academia, science and data analysis, from first semester students to tenured researchers. Leading R-Ladies from around the world will lead us through the most fundamental steps to studying and working in academia, from analyzing results, to presenting them clearly, ensuring their reproducibility, and keeping track of all your changes. The series will close with a panel discussion from women around the world, who will speak about their experiences with science.

This series is funded by the “Pädagogische Hochschule Freiburg”, the University of Education in Freiburg.

Participants who take part in all five meetups can receive a certificate of participation.

Everyone is welcome to join and we hope for a warm exchange between students and researchers, as well as R-Ladies from the wider community.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {Part 2: Tidy data} From Zero to (s)Hero: Multi-part intro to R  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Just getting involved with R or want to level up your skills? Have you used base-R but are still trying to wrap your head around the tidyverse "pipe" (%>%)? Have a messy dataset and don't know where to start? Seen beautiful visualizations on Twitter and want to make your own?

If you’ve answered ‘yes’ to at least one of these questions, fear no more! In this monthly workshop series, we will walk you through the fundamental uses of tidyverse and ggplot at your own pace with the help of hands-on exercises. Tidyverse and ggplot are a classic combination of R packages that allow you to "wrangle" your unwieldy data into whatever shape you need and creative beautiful and informative visualizations.

Over the course of this series, you will learn the most useful features of R Studio and R Markdown, how to read in and explore data, and transform it into a shape that's easy to work with. You will be able to create new columns and summary tables, subset interesting rows or columns, and combine and reshape dataframes. We will also dive into ggplot, one of the best tools for creating great-looking bar charts, scatterplots, and more!

This is (currently) a five-part series, aimed at total beginners and/or people with some experience in base-R or tidyverse who are looking to freshen up or expand their skills. Feel free to join at any point, we will briefly review the previous topic at the beginning of each session.

January 20th {Part 1}: The R & R-Studio ABCs (packages, files, data types & basic data exploration)
Watch here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NO6ikdBxSwg&t=291s

February 17th {Part 2}: Tidy data & introduction to data wrangling (tibbles, renaming, reordering, subsetting)
March 17th {Part 3}: Data wrangling with dplyr (new columns, if-else statements, summary tables, joining dataframes)
April 21st {Part 4}: Introduction to visualizations with ggplot (line graphs, bar charts, scatterplots, histograms, and more!)
May 19th {Part 5}: Advanced topics in wrangling and ggplot (pivoting, ggplot style options, etc.)

Please install R and R-Studio before joining: https://rstudio-education.github.io/hopr/starting.html
AND if you're new to R, catch up on Session 1 with our recorded Meetup: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NO6ikdBxSwg&t=291s

Image by the amazing @allison_horst: https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: {Part 4: Visualization} From Zero to (s)Hero: Multi-part intro to R  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Just getting involved with R or want to level up your skills? Have you used base-R but are still trying to wrap your head around the tidyverse "pipe" (%>%)? Have a messy dataset and don't know where to start? Seen beautiful visualizations on Twitter and want to make your own?

If you’ve answered ‘yes’ to at least one of these questions, fear no more! In this monthly workshop series, we will walk you through the fundamental uses of tidyverse and ggplot at your own pace with the help of hands-on exercises. Tidyverse and ggplot are a classic combination of R packages that allow you to "wrangle" your unwieldy data into whatever shape you need and creative beautiful and informative visualizations.

Over the course of this series, you will learn the most useful features of R Studio and R Markdown, how to read in and explore data, and transform it into a shape that's easy to work with. You will be able to create new columns and summary tables, subset interesting rows or columns, and combine and reshape dataframes. We will also dive into ggplot, one of the best tools for creating great-looking bar charts, scatterplots, and more!

This is (currently) a five-part series, aimed at total beginners and/or people with some experience in base-R or tidyverse who are looking to freshen up or expand their skills. Feel free to join at any point, we will briefly review the previous topic at the beginning of each session.

# Speaker
Dr. Gwynn Sturdevant is a post-doctoral fellow at Harvard Business School working on the Science of Science. In her most recent position, she worked on analytical projects in the rail and the aviation sectors including: improving Terminal Arrival Efficiency Rate estimation, developing an algorithm to predict train arrival times in a multi-agency rail operating environment, and developing methods to produce unbiased algorithmic results. Dr. Sturdevant developed an extensive Shiny application to assist in balancing trials as a post-doctoral fellow with Ken Kleinman (University of Massachusetts, Amherst and Harvard University). Dr. Sturdevant has a PhD in Statistics from the University of Auckland, the birthplace of R, where she studied under Thomas Lumley (University of Auckland and University of Washington) and Ross Ihaka. She focused on finding long-term effects, after cessation of treatments, when noisy measurements cross a threshold in biometric data

title: AthensR: Online event: Workshop Generalized Linear Models Part 2  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

New year, new meetup! We're back in February with part 2 of the Generalized Linear Models workshop by Bodo Winter.

In part one, Bodo Winter gave an introduction to linear models and generalized linear models. This second workshop will introduce participants to mixed models, which are otherwise known as multilevel models or sometimes also hierarchical linear models. These models are crucial for dealing with cases of non-independence, such as when multiple data points are collected from the same individual, or from the same school, district, institution, country, or any other grouping variable. After a brief conceptual introduction, the workshop gives a quick tutorial on how to use the lme4 and afex packages to fit a generalized linear mixed effects model in R.

Please feel welcomed even if you didn’t make it to the first session as Bodo will begin with a very quick recap of part one anyway.

In case you want to see what was covered in part one, here is a link to a recording of the first session: https://bit.ly/35CwxVz

A repo with access to the hands-on materials will be distributed closer to the date of the workshop.

title: R-Ladies Amsterdam: [ONLINE]- Introduction to Network analysis in R  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
Hi, everybody!
We hope that you and your family are doing well. We are super excited to have Jill de Ron, PhD student at the psychological methods department of the University of Amsterdam (UvA) to bring you a workshop on Network analysis in R!

DESCRIPTION
-------------------
We can use networks to provide insights into a variety of settings: A network connecting our Facebook friends gains understanding in our social structure; a human contact network gains insight into disease transmission; and a network of public transport lines informs us about the most central subway stations. In these examples, the relationships between components in the network are known. But in a lot of other cases, the relationships between components are unknown and are what we are interested in. For example, when we want to investigate the relationships between different personality traits. Network psychometrics makes it possible to estimate relationships between a large number of variables. Once you estimated a network, you can perform network-based statistics that give you information about the network’s local and global characteristics. In this workshop, you will learn how to estimate, analyze and interpret (psychological) network models. After a short introduction to network models, we will follow by a tutorial on analyzing data with network models.

PROGRAMME
----------------------
18.30- 18.45 Virtual Welcome
18.45- 20.30 Workshop and Q&A

ABOUT JILL
-------------------
I am a PhD student at the psychological methods department of the University of Amsterdam (UvA). My research is concerned with computational models of anxiety disorders and (formal) theory construction in psychology. I have a master’s degree in both Behavioral Data Science and Psychology. During my master programs I have been teaching assistant for the network analysis course at the UvA.

PREREQUISITES
-----------------------
A basic knowledge of R is recommended. To join the tutorial, please install the bootnet package and the qgraph package.

CODE OF CONDUCT
----------------------------
We expect all attendees to abide by our Code of Conduct. Anyone who violates this community's Code of Conduct will be refused entry, expelled, and/or any other action deemed appropriate by the Organizer, regardless of event registration, meetup membership or other condition. We are emphatically queer and trans-friendly. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn.

[Code of Conduct]

• 20:40 ~ 21:10 (30 mins) 與 Rladies 們聊聊天 -- 讓我們一起規劃未來的 Meetup
• 21:10 ~ 自由交流時間

[Talk Information]
• Voice of Data 如何為你手中的數據發聲
不管是數據分析師、工程師或科學家，在數據團隊建立或轉職初期，甚至是在安插在其他部門內的數據分析工作者，都將面臨來自四面八方的期待，期待你透過分析工具及模型來「點石成金」。但真實情況是你會面臨數據缺失、老闆非技術研究出身、上台報告時台下聽不懂、研究開發資源不到位、講了建議後執行團隊不理你等等情況。
這個演講將融匯 Sally 在美國及中國遇到文化衝擊的小故事及解決方案，希望帶給在職場上為數據發聲的工作者，能更有勇氣與影響力。

• 與 Rladies 們聊聊天 -- 讓我們一起規劃未來的 Meetup
2020 因為疫情我們休息了一整年, 2021 我們決定重出江湖
但我們想藉由久違付出的這次, 跟大家一起討論未來 Meetup 的方向和形式
希望有大家的參與可以讓舊朋友和新朋友們都可以更融入 R-Ladies Taipei

[Speaker Information]
• Sally
從百貨採購轉跳成數據分析師與科學家的 Sally，在數據職涯中歷經美國與中國企業文化，橫跨金融、醫藥、音樂娛樂與數位教育等產業，做過分析及建置數據產品開發團隊。
目前在台灣美商 Viewsonic 做數據科學家。

• Summit Suen：聯絡講者、活動場地

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - Algorithms of Oppression  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Algorithms of Oppression (https://www.bookdepository.com/Algorithms-Oppression-Safiya-Umoja-Noble/9781479837243).

A revealing look at how negative biases against women of color are embedded in search engine results and algorithms

Run a Google search for "black girls"-what will you find? "Big Booty" and other sexually explicit terms are likely to come up as top search terms. But, if you type in "white girls," the results are radically different. The suggested porn sites and un-moderated discussions about "why black women are so sassy" or "why black women are so angry" presents a disturbing portrait of black womanhood in modern society.

In Algorithms of Oppression, Safiya Umoja Noble challenges the idea that search engines like Google offer an equal playing field for all forms of ideas, identities, and activities. Data discrimination is a real social problem; Noble argues that the combination of private interests in promoting certain sites, along with the monopoly status of a relatively small number of Internet search engines, leads to a biased set of search algorithms that privilege whiteness and discriminate against people of color, specifically women of color.

Through an analysis of textual and media searches as well as extensive research on paid online advertising, Noble exposes a culture of racism and sexism in the way discoverability is created online. As search engines and their related companies grow in importance-operating as a source for email, a major vehicle for primary and secondary school learning, and beyond-understanding and reversing these disquieting trends and discriminatory practices is of utmost importance.

An original, surprising and, at times, disturbing account of bias on the internet, Algorithms of Oppression contributes to our understanding of how racism is created, maintained, and disseminated in the 21st century.

PS Please contact the organizer if you need support finding the book.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Hacking My Way into Interactive Graphic with Flourish.  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Bio: Jasmine Ye Han is a data reporter, cooking enthusiast and plant parent. She moved to the U.S. from China six years ago and now lives in Maryland. She has a master's degree in journalism from University of Missouri. Her journey in R coding started in 2017.

Abstract:
Most journalists complain about their CMS. So do I (shhh). When I felt confined by a CMS with limited capability of working with interactive graphics (and lack of D3 skills), Flourish came to my rescue. With built-in templates, it creates interactive maps, charts, and tables in seconds. Add a few tips and tricks to work around some of the limitations, anyone can create beautiful interactives customizable to your needs.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: International Women's Day Celebration: Data science for social equality  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Abstract: Our society remains profoundly unequal. This talk presents vignettes about how data science can be used to combat inequality, focusing on public health and healthcare as application areas.

Bio: Emma Pierson is a senior researcher at Microsoft Research and an incoming assistant professor of computer science at Cornell Tech. She develops data science and machine learning methods to study inequality and healthcare. Her work has been recognized by a Rhodes Scholarship, Hertz Fellowship, Rising Star in EECS, and Forbes 30 Under 30 in Science. She has written for The New York Times, FiveThirtyEight, The Atlantic, The Washington Post, Wired, and various other publications.

# Speaker
Dr. Gwynn Sturdevant is a post-doctoral fellow at Harvard Business School working on the Science of Science. In her most recent position, she worked on analytical projects in the rail and the aviation sectors including: improving Terminal Arrival Efficiency Rate estimation, developing an algorithm to predict train arrival times in a multi-agency rail operating environment, and developing methods to produce unbiased algorithmic results. Dr. Sturdevant developed an extensive Shiny application to assist in balancing trials as a post-doctoral fellow with Ken Kleinman (University of Massachusetts, Amherst and Harvard University). Dr. Sturdevant has a PhD in Statistics from the University of Auckland, the birthplace of R, where she studied under Thomas Lumley (University of Auckland and University of Washington) and Ross Ihaka. She focused on finding long-term effects, after cessation of treatments, when noisy measurements cross a threshold in biometric data

Description:
------------
Fantasy Premier League (https://fantasy.premierleague.com) is one of the worlds most popular online fantasy sports games with ~7 million players. During the[masked] season we undertook a large data scraping exercise to obtain data describing the manager's selections over the year, along with a number of other statistics on the actual footballers upon which the game is based.

In this talk we will firstly introduce our dataset before proceeding to discuss the dynamics and actions of the game's managers via a number of statistical tools and visualizations obtained through R and the tidyverse, with the hope of determining whether the top (fantasy) mangers earn their title through certain skills and if so what skills?

title: Dublin R: #GlobalR: {ggstatsplot}- Creating {ggplot2}-Based Plots With Statistical Details, Ireland, Europe
description:
This event is organized by the Oslo useR! meetup group: https://www.meetup.com/Oslo-useR-Group/events/275861577

[Abstract]
{ggstatsplot} is an extension of the {ggplot2} package for creating
graphics with details from statistical tests, included in the information-rich plots themselves.
In a typical exploratory data analysis workflow, data visualization and statistical modeling are two different phases: visualization informs modeling, and modeling in turn can suggest a different visualization method, and so on and so forth.
The central idea of {ggstatsplot} is simple: combine these two phases into one in the form of graphics with statistical details, which makes data exploration simpler and faster!

[Bio]
Indrajeet Patil is a Postdoctoral Researcher at the Center for Humans and Machines, Max Planck Institute for Human Development, Berlin. He has a Ph.D. in cognitive neuroscience and specializes in investigating the psychological and neural basis of moral judgment and decision-making. He is also an active R package developer and part of the {easystats} team.

# Description
Life as member of a data team is awesome but as a lone data scientist in a small company you have to be data engineer, IT consultant and data scientist all in one. So how do you get your R scripts to run? In this talk I hope to inspire lone data scientists on all the ways you can run your Rscript in the cloud. I cover some simple and more advanced use cases for running R in the cloud. I also talk about cooperating with IT for maximum results.

# Speaker
I'm a maker, I love to build useful (machine learning) tools for people and I love sharing what I learned. I have been working in researcher, data scientist and machine learning engineer roles for the past years. I want to make it easy, convenient and simple for everyone to run their R work in the cloud. I also really like dogs, my girlfriend and I are getting one soon!

title: Seattle useR Group (R Programming Language): Build a Career in Data Science  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For this meetup Seattle UseR Group is pleased to give an opportunity for its members to hear from Emily Robinson and Dr. Jacqueline Nolis on their new book "Building a Career in Data Science".

Emily Robinson is a senior data scientist at Warby Parker, where she works on a centralized team tackling some of the company's projects. She previously worked at DataCamp, where she built and ran their experimentation analytics system, and at Etsy, where she worked with their search team.

Dr. Jacqueline Nolis is a data science leader with over 15 years of experience in leading data science teams and projects at companies ranging from DSW to Airbnb. She has a PhD in Industrial Engineering, and for fun Jacqueline likes to use data science for humor - like using deep learning to generate offensive license plates.

Authors Emily and Jaqueline will read selections from their book and discuss why parts were personally meaningful and tell stories from their pasts that ended up shaping the narrative. You’ll learn about the overarching themes from the book to help people excel in their data science careers, as well as tips that can be practical for people at all career levels. After Emily and Jacqueline discuss their book, the floor will open so anyone can ask their data science career questions.

title: Canberra R Users Group: AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit - Sydney 2021, Australia, Australia
description:
Registration is required on the AlphaZetta site - links below.

The AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit is a unique conference experience, built around experts sharing their knowledge, use cases, best practice and having time for meaningful interactions. It is not vendor driven - there’s no booths or selling and no big crowds - we expect only ~150 attendees. The summit provides insightful presentations, fantastic networking and discussion time at great value!

We are delighted that the next GAS will be held in Sydney on Friday 5th March at the Manly Pacific Hotel. Further details including the agenda can be found here ( https://alphazetta.ai/event/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020/ ).

The day starts with presentations on the current state of the analytics market and key trends to look for in the future. The second section is about inspiring attendees with keynotes from Volt Bank on creating a new business based on data and analytics and from Raiffeisen Bank on building an analytics team to provide true value to the whole organisation.

The afternoon focuses on innovation and implementation. We have presentations from some of Australia’s exciting startups (Volt, Adgile Media, Self Assured Pty Ltd) who are using analytics to disrupt their markets. To close, we will hear a keynote on how to deliver analytics and increase AI adoption.

The Summit venue is the Novotel Pacific, Manly which is right on the ocean beach, with lunch and dinner included.

All up, at just $350 for standard tickets, it’s a conference like no other!

Here’s a video clip to highlight all of the above! (https://youtu.be/YKnFo0thEMM)

Presenters Include:
Steve Weston - Co-Founder and CEO, Volt Bank
Stephen Brobst - AlphaZetta Advisory Board; Chief Technology Officer, Teradata; TDWI Fellow
Felipe Flores - Founder, Data Futurology; GM Data Science and Analytics, Liberty Financial
Martin Endrizal, BI Application Operations Manager, Vodafone Czech Republic
Markus Lochner - Head of Group Digital Solutions, Raiffeisen Bank International
Tony Ohlsson - Founder, AlphaZetta; Chief Analytics Officer, Volt Bank

PLEASE DO NOT RSVP ON MEETUP.COM.
Further details including the agenda can be found here ( https://alphazetta.ai/event/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020/ )
Tickets are available here ( https://www.eventbrite.sg/e/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020-tickets-85943209453 )

title: R-Ladies St. Louis:  Plotting vaccination intention: An intro to data viz in R with ggplot2  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Please join R-Ladies St. Louis in welcoming Zoey Dlott (left) and Megan Richard (right) for an introduction to creating data visualizations with ggplot2. Zoey and Megan will demonstrate the basics of ggplot2 using some very timely survey data measuring intention to get the covid vaccine.

Zoey is an advanced standing MSW student at Washington University, is interested in healthcare accessibility and in her free time enjoys baking and exploring coffee shops. Megan is a first year MPH student at Washington University who is passionate about the environment and sweet tea.

More details forthcoming closer to the event date.

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Introduction to Time Series in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join R-Ladies St. Louis as we welcome Laura Rose from Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals. Laura is planning an introductory workshop on time series in R that is geared toward people who have not done time series before but who *do have* some experience with using R and R Studio. Time series is used with data collected over time at close intervals. Laura uses time series to forecast demand.

More details forthcoming!

title: R-Ladies Seattle: Tutorial: Introduction to Parallel Processing in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Please join us for a lunchtime R-Ladies meetup with Brittany Barker. Brittany will guide us through a beginner-level tutorial on how and why to use parallel computing in R.

Brittany is a Research Associate (Postdoc) at the Oregon IPM Center at Oregon State University, where she is developing a spatial modeling platform (written in R) that predicts phenology and climate suitability of invasive insect species in real-time. She is broadly interested in how environmental perturbations such as climate change shape the population dynamics and geographical range limits of plant and animal species.

In her demo, she will demonstrate the use and value of the parallel, doParallel, and foreach packages for parallel computing in R. The demo will center on analyzing very large spatial data sets, but parallel processing in R can be used for ANY type of data. She will provide examples of when you may want to use parallel computing for your work, and provide further resources to explore.

This demo will be held over zoom and we will RStudio Cloud so you can follow along with the Brittany's code. We will email out instructions on what to expect and how to get set up.

title: R-Ladies Dallas: Flexdashboard tutorial with Kaelen Medeiros  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Happy New Year! For the February edition of our R-Ladies Dallas webinar series, we are excited to welcome Kaelen Medeiros as our guest speaker. Kaelen will introduce the topic of flexdashboards.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Session title: Let’s Build a Flexdashboard!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Abstract: Don’t want to stand up an entire Shiny app to make a quick dashboard, but you know RMarkdown? Enter flexdashboard, which allows you to create a dashboard using a RMarkdown file. In this short workshop, we’ll build a flexdashboard by exploring and visualizing metrics for a pre-specified open dataset. We’ll learn the basics of flexdashboard while brainstorm dashboard design ideas, calculate and display our metrics, and discuss possible deployment options.

Bio: Kaelen is a data scientist at Medidata Solutions where they work as an R programmer on the microservices team. They've also worked at Spring Health, DataCamp, HERE Technologies, and have done a fair amount of R and Shiny consulting on the side. Kaelen has been at various times in their life a film theorist, preschool teacher, test prep tutor, videographer, and nanny before getting a MS in Biostatistics from LSU Health Sciences Center in 2016 and starting work as a statistician and data scientist. Outside of work they enjoy podcasts, cats, aliens, nail polish, and data.

title: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup: January Meet-up: Dean Attali & Caterina Constantinescu  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
group: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup
description:
Caterina Constantinescu (Tesco Bank)

Title: Speeding up your Shiny App

You've built a Shiny app with a variety of features, and now users have
started to rely on it to complete their daily tasks. But what happens
if, with repeated use, they start to grow impatient and would like it to
run faster, or if the userbase increases and the app cannot easily cope
with the growing demand? We are suddenly in the realm of performance
optimisation. But what does this entail? In this introductory talk, I
will mention some principles and tools to help you along this journey:
from how you should think about performance improvements before you even
get started, to how you should test, measure or boost performance with
tools such as {shinyloadtest} or {profvis}, or caching and more.

----------

Dean Attali (https://deanattali.com/) is a Shiny Consultant based in Canada. If you have you used Shiny, you will have almost certainly used one of Dean's packages.

Title: TBC, but something Shiny related

This talk will involve a significant amount of live coding around R & Shiny. While the talk will be suitable for everyone it is primarily aimed for participants with some experience in R and Shiny.

title: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup: March Meet-up  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
group: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup
description: Alastair Rushworth (Tesco Bank)
